answers.answer: Hi,You mentioned about an MRI being done.Do you have the results?Migraine has been shown to be associated with silent MRI changes such as white matter abnormalities (WMA).The signficance of these findings are yet to be defined. Complex migraines have to be differentiated from a stroke through a complete neurologic and physical examination. CT Scan and MRI may supplement and help confirm the focus if this is  a stroke.Migraines however are of a different mechanism. They are associated with the dilation and spasm of blood vessels.Headaches appear during vasodilation and neurologic deficits may appear during spasms.Second opinion may help since these conditions may also be present in other diseases like multiple sclerosis, medication side effects,diabetes and vitamin deficiencies.Further tests might be required to rule out these other differentials.I hope this helps.Keep us posted for anything.
no I don't have mri report but am going to get whole file and films for second opinion

MRI ResultsThere are two small foci of T2 and FLAIR hyperintense signal, one within deep white matter of the anterior right parietal lobe and the other within the deep white matter of the posterior lobe.  No space-occupying mass lesions or abnormal enhancement.  On diffusion imaging, no acute of subacute infarctImpression:Two small foci of T2 and Flair hyperintense signal involving the white matter of both cerebral hemispheres.  The one involving the posterior left parietal white matter was present previously.  The anterior right parietal lobe white matter lesion cannot be identified with certainty on the prior study and may represent a new finding.

HI, who told you it was just complex migraine?  A doctor or neurologist?  I personally if I were you definately get a second opinion and if you have not already seen one, see a neurologists.  Agree that more testing needs to be done if they havnt already been done.Blood tests etc.  Was there just an MRI of brain? What about MRI if spine/spinal cord?Whilst there are types of migraines out there that can cause some symptoms without headache if you do not feel happy with this diagnosis then definately get a second opinion.Good luck
a neurologist told me, but I willbe seeing a new neurologist on wednesday.  thanks

Have you had blood tests done? I suffer from prolonged auras and I am a registered nurse and have researched treatment for it and have been seeing a neurologist for over a year and a half. Have you been worked up for Multiple Sclerosis or Lupus, both of which can cause the symptoms you are having as well as changes on MRI. Have you heard of a hemipalegic migraine? Sometimes those suffering from complex migraine can have this form which causes numbness timgling and even paralysis. My motto is when in doubt ALWAYS get a second oppinion and research this stuff yourself too.

question: yesterday I was told I suffer from complex migraine, she started me on lamictal.  My question is this. I had an MRI in summer of 2006 and another last week.  There were changes, I was told, on MRI due to these migraines.  My symptoms come about every 6 months and last about a month or so.  They include, blurry vision, vertigo, muscle twitching, muscle spasms, stomach upset, heart palpitation, fatigue,  vibration feeling in legs and feet, neck pain and confusion.  This last time I had such pains in my legs that I had trouble walking.  These symptoms are not always with a headache. Is this common with complex migraines? This length of time? Should I seek a second opinion?thanksslpc
title: complex migraines
